title: Calculating associations using corVis
text: association measure can defined numerical summary quantifying relationship two variables. example, Pearson’s correlation coefficient summarizes strength direction linear relationship present two numeric variables range \([-1,1]\). Similarly, distance correlation coefficient measures non-linear association two numeric variables summarizes \([0,1]\) \(0\) suggests non-linear relationship \(1\) suggests high non-linear relationship. title: Calculating associations using corVis
text: introduce method creates tibble structure variable pairs dataset along calculated association measure. package contains various functions (shown Table 1) different association measures form tbl_* calculate . example, user might interested calculating distance correlation numeric pair variables dataset. can done using tbl_dcor. what: Calculating association measures for whole dataset
title: Calculating associations using corVis
text: calc_assoc can used calculate association measures variable pairs dataset tibble structure. addition tibble structure, output also pairwise data.frame class important class attributes producing visual summaries package. function types argument basically tibble association measure calculated different variable pairs. default tibble measures default_assoc() calculates Pearson’s correlation variables numeric, Kendall’s tau-b variables ordinal, canonical correlation one factor numeric canonical correlation rest variable pairs. analyst can update measures using update_assoc function one can specify tbl_* function calculate association measure depending variable pair dataset method calculates one measure. tibble output calc_assoc following structure: x y representing pair variables measure representing calculated value association measure measure_type representing association measure calculated x y pair. variable pairs output unique pairs subset variable pairs dataset x \(\neq\) y. explained earlier, measure_type represents association measure calculated specific type variable pair. user can interested calculating multiple association measures type variable pair. can done using calc_assoc update_assoc together calculating different association measures merging output tibbles.
code: complete_assoc <- calc_assoc(df) glimpse(complete_assoc) ## Rows: 28 ## Columns: 5 ## $ x            <chr> "island", "bill_length_mm", "bill_depth_mm", "flipper_len… ## $ y            <chr> "species", "species", "species", "species", "species", "s… ## $ measure      <dbl> 0.81328762, 0.84131393, 0.82447508, 0.88217284, 0.8183348… ## $ measure_type <chr> "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor… ## $ pair_type    <chr> "ff", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "ff", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf… class(complete_assoc) ## [1] "pairwise"   "tbl_df"     "tbl"        "data.frame" default_measures <- update_assoc() default_measures ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   funName     typeX   typeY   argList ##   <chr>       <chr>   <chr>   <list>  ## 1 tbl_cor     numeric numeric <NULL>  ## 2 tbl_cancor  factor  factor  <NULL>  ## 3 tbl_gkGamma ordered ordered <NULL>  ## 4 tbl_cancor  factor  numeric <NULL> updated_assoc <- update_assoc(num_pair = "tbl_cor",                               num_pair_argList = "spearman",                               mixed_pair = "tbl_cancor",                               other_pair = "tbl_nmi") updated_assoc ## # A tibble: 4 × 4 ##   funName     typeX   typeY   argList   ##   <chr>       <chr>   <chr>   <list>    ## 1 tbl_cor     numeric numeric <chr [1]> ## 2 tbl_cancor  factor  factor  <NULL>    ## 3 tbl_gkGamma ordered ordered <NULL>    ## 4 tbl_cancor  factor  numeric <NULL> updated_complete_assoc <- calc_assoc(df, types = updated_assoc) glimpse(updated_complete_assoc) ## Rows: 28 ## Columns: 5 ## $ x            <chr> "island", "bill_length_mm", "bill_depth_mm", "flipper_len… ## $ y            <chr> "species", "species", "species", "species", "species", "s… ## $ measure      <dbl> 0.81328762, 0.84131393, 0.82447508, 0.88217284, 0.8183348… ## $ measure_type <chr> "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor… ## $ pair_type    <chr> "ff", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "ff", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf…

text: calc_assoc can also used calculate association measures variable pairs different levels categorical variable. can help exploring conditional associations find interesting patterns data prior modeling. output function data structure cond_pairwise, data.frame, tibble class attributes. argument used grouping variable needs categorical. function also types argument can updated similarly calc_assoc. default, function calculates association measures variable pairs different levels grouping variable pairwise association measures ungrouped data (overall). behavior can changed setting include.overall FALSE. variable pairs output repeated every level variable.
code: complete_assoc_by <- calc_assoc(df,by = "sex") updated_assoc <- update_assoc(num_pair = "tbl_cor",                               num_pair_argList = "spearman",                               mixed_pair = "tbl_cancor",                               other_pair = "tbl_nmi") updated_complete_assoc_by <- calc_assoc(df,by = "sex", types = updated_assoc) glimpse(updated_complete_assoc_by) ## Rows: 84 ## Columns: 6 ## $ x            <chr> "island", "bill_length_mm", "bill_depth_mm", "flipper_len… ## $ y            <chr> "species", "species", "species", "species", "species", "s… ## $ measure      <dbl> 0.80923103, 0.88495341, 0.89966135, 0.91412697, 0.9106057… ## $ measure_type <chr> "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor", "cancor… ## $ by           <fct> female, female, female, female, female, female, female, f… ## $ pair_type    <chr> "ff", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf", "nf… complete_assoc_by <- calc_assoc(df,by = "sex",include.overall = FALSE)

title: Exploring pairwise associations with scagnostics and corVis
text: Scagnostics Paul John Tukey’s (1985) idea defining measures characterize scatterplot. idea plot \(\frac{p \times (p-1)}{2}\) scatterplots, \(p\) number variables, points scatterplot matrix \(k\) measures can used find subsets interesting scatterplots. suggested possible measures scatterplot density, shape, trend, outliers. Wilkinson et al [1] proposed graph-theoretic scagnostic measures based three geometric graphs: convex hull, alpha hull minimum spanning tree (mst) highlight unusual scatterplots. presented nine measures quantified density, shape, trend outliers scatterplot. nine measures - Outlying Skewed Clumpy Sparse Striated Convex Skinny Monotonic

title: Exploring pairwise associations with scagnostics and corVis
text: package corVis function tbl_scag calculating scagnostic measures tibble structure numeric variable pairs dataset. tbl_scag function calculates scagnostic measures using scagnostics package R. tbl_scag uses dataset scagnostic measure two main inputs outputs tibble variable pairs calculated scagnostic measure. default, scagnostic measure calculated Outlying quantifies presence outliers scatterplot. also provide functionality handling missing values using pairwise complete observations. Similarly, scagnostic measures caulculated updating scagnostic argument tbl_scag function. tbl_scag returns tibble variable pairs calculated measure, also additional classes pairwise data.frame. pairwise measures association tibble dataframe structure, outputs used packages like dplyr , ggplot2 exploration scagnostic measures.

title: Exploring pairwise associations with scagnostics and corVis
text: Following Tukey’s idea scatterplot matrix display measures, propose linear display comparison multiple scagnostic measures numeric variable pairs dataset. useful identifying unusual scatterplots variable pairs. pairwise_1d_compare produces linear display comparing multiple scagnostic measures. takes calculated scagnostic measures input displays variable pairs Y-axis scagnostic measures X-axis. Figure 2 shows comparison scagnostic measures penguins dataset. fill cell corresponds value scagnostic measure. variable pair flipper length bill depth Figure 2 shows high value clumpy monotonic measures suggesting presence clusters points monotonic relationship two variables. low value clumpy high value monotonic scagnostic measure variable pair body mass flipper length suggests strong association among two variables penguins every species. Figure 2: Comparing multiple scagnostic measures using linear layout
code: outlying <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Outlying") skewed <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Skewed") clumpy <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Clumpy") sparse <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Sparse") striated <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Striated") convex <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Convex") skinny <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Skinny") stringy <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Stringy") monotonic <- tbl_scag(df,scagnostic = "Monotonic")  scag_measures <- rbind(outlying, skewed, clumpy, sparse, striated, convex, skinny, stringy,                        monotonic) plot_assoc_linear(scag_measures, limits = c(0,1))

code: df_num <- dplyr::select(df,where(is.numeric)) pearson <- calc_assoc(df_num)  spearman_assoc <- update_assoc(num_pair = "tbl_cor",                                num_pair_argList= "spearman",                                mixed_pair = "tbl_cancor",                                other_pair = "tbl_nmi") spearman <- calc_assoc(df_num, types=spearman_assoc) compare <- rbind(pearson,spearman) plot_assoc_matrix(compare) pearson <- tbl_cor(df,method="pearson") spearman <- tbl_cor(df,method="spearman") kendall <- tbl_cor(df,method="kendall") cancor <- tbl_cancor(df) nmi <- tbl_nmi(df)  assoc <- rbind(pearson, spearman, kendall, cancor, nmi) plot_assoc_linear(assoc)
